G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts governing residential tenancies, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common law covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in residential leases.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: The amount in controversy is less than $50,000, and this Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and applicable rules of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department because the Premises are located in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has had responsibility for providing and maintaining essential services to the Premises, including hot water, in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. 410.190.proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.190 and related provisions of the State Sanitary Code, a landlord of a residential dwelling in Massachusetts is required to provide and maintain facilities capable of heating water to prescribed minimum temperatures for bathing and cleaning.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and settled case law, compliance with the State Sanitary Code is an implied condition of every residential tenancy.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and settled case law, compliance with the State Sanitary Code is an implied condition of every residential tenancy. See, e.g., *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 187–88 (1973).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but he expressly states the rule that the landlord, by renting, impliedly agrees to comply with the minimum standards of the State Sanitary Code and that these obligations are for the benefit of the tenant. The majority in Hemingway is well known for adopting an implied warranty of habitability grounded in the State Sanitary Code, and Quirico’s opinion underscores that Code compliance is an implied term of the tenancy. Thus, while this segment is not the core majority holding and frames the issue as an implied agreement rather than using § 8A directly, the case overall supports the proposition that compliance with the State Sanitary Code is an implied condition of residential tenancies.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, codified and protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14, and by common law. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the “quiet enjoyment” clause of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains that the statute uses a term with a well‑developed common‑law background. It squarely states that every tenancy includes an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, and treats § 14 as protecting that right. Thus, the case supports the proposition that Massachusetts residential leases contain an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, recognized both at common law and through § 14.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.” (385 Mass. at 101–02)

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: The continued absence of hot water for an extended period is a serious violation of the State Sanitary Code and constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case clearly treats loss of heat and hot water as a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability where the premises fail to comply with the State Sanitary Code, and it ties habitability to the existence of substantial Sanitary Code violations. While the opinion focuses on rent abatement rather than explicitly using the phrase “quiet enjoyment,” Massachusetts law often treats substantial habitability breaches/Code violations as substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment, so the case is reasonably good authority for the proposition, though not a direct quiet-enjoyment holding. The support is therefore inferential rather than express.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “The landlord would have us avert our eyes from the clear teaching of Hemingway. ‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969)….”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: The continued absence of hot water for an extended period is a serious violation of the State Sanitary Code and constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion in Blackett v. Olanoff deals with constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment caused by excessive noise from a bar the landlord permitted to operate; it does not involve lack of hot water or violations of the State Sanitary Code. While it affirms that substantial interferences with habitability can breach quiet enjoyment, it provides no specific authority that an extended absence of hot water is a serious State Sanitary Code violation or, by itself, constitutes such a breach. Thus it is not accurate support for the precise proposition stated.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord is strictly liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord, “directly or indirectly, by himself or his servants or other persons acting for him, interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” See *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982) (landlord’s liability under § 14 does not require intent to harm, only that the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s action or inaction is interference with quiet enjoyment).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and explicitly states that intent to violate the covenant is not required; the landlord’s conduct and its natural and probable consequences control. This aligns with the proposition that liability under § 14 is effectively strict, based on interference with quiet enjoyment, regardless of intent to harm or financial inability, so long as the landlord’s action or inaction naturally results in interference.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to…a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 61 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The extended failure to provide hot water, an essential service required by law, constitutes such an interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, even if Defendant did not subjectively intend to harm Plaintiff.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 61 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns equitable rights to life insurance proceeds under a separation agreement and constructive trusts based on unjust enrichment. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, habitability, essential services, hot water, or statutory quiet enjoyment. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses interference with quiet enjoyment or the irrelevance of a defendant’s subjective intent, so it cannot be valid authority for the stated proposition.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 61 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Hurley, having furnished no consideration for the receipt of the proceeds of the life insurance policies, has received a gratuitous benefit and would be unjustly enriched in the eyes of the law were he to retain those proceeds against the claims of Foster. But this is not to suggest that Hurley acted improperly: unjust enrichment is not necessarily ‘unlawful’ or ‘wrongful’ enrichment."

*Leardi v. Brown*, 394 Mass. 151, 159\u2.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a tenant who establishes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment is entitled to recover actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs. See *Berman & Sons*, 379 Mass. at 199–202; *Leardi v. Brown*, 394 Mass. 151, 159–63 (1985).
*Leardi v. Brown*, 394 Mass. 151, 159\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely quotes and applies the remedial language of G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that a violator "shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month's rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney's fee." Although the court ultimately finds no substantial interference and thus no violation for Allisan, its description of the statute confirms that tenants who do establish a § 14 breach are entitled to the greater of actual/consequential damages or three months’ rent plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. This matches the proposition.
*Leardi v. Brown*, 394 Mass. 151, 159\u2.relevant_excerpt: The relevant portion of G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended through St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, provides that: "[A]ny lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant, or who attempts to regain possession of such premises by force without benefit of judicial process, shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars nor more than three hundred dollars, or by imprisonment for not more than six months. Any person who commits any act in violation of this section shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month's rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney's fee..."

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Guirola*, 410 Mas.proposition: The prolonged lack of hot water at the Premises—approximately three weeks or more—constitutes a serious and substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her home and violates the State Sanitary Code and the implied warranty of habitability.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Guirola*, 410 Mas.support_reasoning: The case concerns termination of a public housing tenancy for drug activity and the applicability of G. L. c. 139, § 19, double jeopardy, and the exclusionary rule. It does not address conditions of habitability, lack of hot water, the State Sanitary Code, or the implied warranty of habitability. Nothing in the opinion discusses interference with use and enjoyment of the premises due to inadequate services or utilities, so it cannot be authority for the proposition about prolonged lack of hot water constituting a serious and substantial interference and a sanitary code/warranty violation.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Guirola*, 410 Mas.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 139, § 19 (1990 ed.), authorizes a landlord to void a lease if a “tenant or occupant . . . uses such premises . . . for . . . the illegal keeping, sale or manufacture of controlled substances” (emphasis added). Guirola argues that the statute applies only to conduct by the tenant herself. She argues that the evidence suggested at most that Taylor possessed the drugs, and that there was no evidence that she or her family knew of or were in any way involved with their presence.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: The prolonged lack of hot water at the Premises—approximately three weeks or more—constitutes a serious and substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her home and violates the State Sanitary Code and the implied warranty of habitability.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a statutory violation (the lead paint statute) automatically constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that it does not; at least negligent conduct with notice is required. It does not address lack of hot water, the State Sanitary Code’s hot-water requirements, habitability, or what constitutes a serious and substantial interference with use and enjoyment in that context. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about three weeks without hot water violating the Sanitary Code and implied warranty of habitability.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”
